About Humans Preferences An Introduction to Web Architecture

📐 Architecting the Web HTML–first

Lesson 3.7.0

Written by JP de Vries

Improve this Page

Why do your users show up? Odds are it is for content. Deliver content interpretively as HTML to ensure content is accessible pic.twitter.com/21i5XZkPwK

— Markup Tips (@mrktps) November 3, 2016

“If you want to understand [how your design works within the viewport], you need to build it in HTML and CSS” @jensimmons #smashingconf

— Stephen Hay (@stephenhay) October 26, 2016

Many musician go aucoustic first when writing music.

HTML is an acoustic guitar. Start there.

Rock out with electric JavaScript later.

— JP de Vries (@jpdevries) October 21, 2016

“Design requires restraints.”

A great reason to start with HTML–first. https://t.co/GUgX0ngpaA

— Markup Tips (@mrktps) October 7, 2016

Use semantic HTML elements. If you can't, use ARIA rules. CSS classes are for developers, not readers.@robinwhittleton at #fen16

— laura kishimoto (@chicgeek) September 30, 2016

Designing future forward isn’t just about code that works better tomorrow.

It’s about supporting accessibility of aging users too.
♿️ 🚀

Ask yourself, “Is this interface usable to your 20yr old target audience in 60 years?“
🎯 📆

— JP de Vries (@jpdevries) January 4, 2017
